topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open highlights Stewart’s relentless dissatisfaction with early Slack quality, plus quick framing of Slack’s customer-value ethos, friction vs comprehension, and the emotional difficulty of pivoting. Lenny introduces Stewart’s background (Flickr, Slack) and previews key topics for the episode.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS (enterprise features APIs) and Metronome (usage-based billing infrastructure).

topics.title: What Stewart is doing after Slack
topics.summary: Stewart shares life post-Salesforce: spending time with family, exploring philanthropic and creative projects, and periodically discussing future ideas with Cal Henderson. He also reflects on the tension of building software while feeling modern tech can be harmful.

topics.title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
topics.summary: Stewart explains the S-curve of effort vs value and how it applies to features and product quality: early work may yield little value until a threshold, then diminishing returns set in. The framework helps teams decide whether to invest more, stop, or rethink a feature.

topics.title: Rising quality bars and neglected UX basics
topics.summary: Stewart discusses “divine discontent” and how user expectations rise over time, requiring continual iteration even on unglamorous flows. He uses Google Calendar’s time zone picker as an example of high-impact UX debt that erodes delight and advocacy.

topics.title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
topics.summary: Stewart defines product “taste” as learnable through practice and argues it’s a competitive advantage because many teams don’t invest in it. He shares the “tilt your umbrella” story as a metaphor for empathy and small courtesies that create emotional connection and word-of-mouth growth.

topics.title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
topics.summary: Concrete examples of delight-driven product choices: magic-link login to avoid mobile password pain, default notifications to help early comprehension, and guided transitions to recommended settings. Stewart emphasizes investing to get users over the initial “hump.”

topics.title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
topics.summary: Stewart explains how features can steer culture: the “shouty rooster” warning discourages abusive @everyone usage by making the cost salient. The goal is to preserve signal-to-noise and teach users how the system works.

topics.title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
topics.summary: A detailed look at launching DND without breaking critical workflows (e.g., ops alerts) across many organizations. Stewart describes admin pre-communication, sensible defaults, and layered override rules balancing org policy with individual control.

topics.title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
topics.summary: Stewart argues “reduce friction” is often misapplied; the real challenge is comprehension when user intent is low and they don’t understand what to do next. He ties this to “Don’t Make Me Think,” cognitive/ emotional costs of confusion, and why fewer taps can be worse than clearer steps.

topics.title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
topics.summary: Stewart shares his infamous 2014 quote calling Slack “a giant piece of shit” as a way to instill perpetual improvement and high standards. He connects this to building trust for direct feedback and treating mistakes as valuable learning opportunities (Michael Jordan skiing story).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read begins for Lovable (build apps/websites by chatting with AI).
